page.lettertext:
fol.11r
May it please yo
r
good L. The
Empero
rs
Ambassado
r
, of whose arrival at the
Hage, I advertised yo
r
L.
e 23 of this moneth, hath surceased his suite
to have audience of this
Councel,
and intendeth to expect
e meetinge
of the states. In w
ch
respect, and for the better dispatche of certaine
deputies, w
ch
are heere residinge from
e Bishop of
Liege,
complai-
ning of
e daily incursions and cruelties,
at are committed by certaine
garrison souldiers appertening to the states, upon his neutral places
and also to the ende it may be knowen in time convenient, w
at
e
Provinces have resolved as touching
e Councels Proposition
made unto them the 5 of No
v
last (wherof at that time I sent
you
r
L. the copie) for the Fournishing of nine hundred thowsand
florins extraordinarie, to be imploied in
e next sommers warre, there
are letters newly written from the Councel of Estate, to everye
Province a part, to hasten
e sending of their deputies hither. So
as nowe it is supposed,
at they will be heere to assemble w
t
in
this fortnight at
e furthest. By this course of
e Ambassado
r
,
the Councel of Estate is somewhat overtaken. For wheras they
had presumed, that he woulde not attend the comming of the states,
but addresse himself to them, wherby they thought, to
at effect, as I
have formerly written, to make him some answear to the contreis
advantage, their hope in
at regard is altogether frustrat. He hath
taken suche advise, as he will deale w
t
noe others, but the states of
e
Contrey. Nevertheles by all that I can conjecture, there is no suspi
tion to be had,
at
e states will be wrought to admitte any Treaty.
To tell yo
r
L. a truth, for mine owne particular I did flately oppose
and so did others of this Councel against the giving of a pasport, to
licence his comming so farre as the Hage. For albeit he professeth
religion, and is a frinde as they say to the cause of these contreis, yet
I thought it was not otherwise to be scann
e
d, but that he would alwaies
be faithfull to his Master the
Empero
r
,
and that he might not happi
ly be acquainted w
t
the Enemies mysteries, and w
t
the mischiefe intended
to the ruine of this state. Wherupon they were to thinke, that before
he would depart w
t
out an absolut answear to
e matter of his message
he would not onely sojorne heere, till
e states were assembled, but
would deale by his ministers and letters w
t
the single Provinces
fol.11v
w
t
e principal townes, and w
t
all those persons in parti[cular]
might steede him in his purpose. And w
at
effectes his [long abode]
and secret practises might produce among a ticklishe peop[le that]
have bin alwaies in those actions inconstant and credulous, [it was]
muche to be considered. For I thinke yo
r
L. doth knowe [it, and I]
see it heere before mine eies, that howsoever the opinion i[s commonly]
conceaved, and they would have it heere conceaved, that the [point]
of religion is a principal occasion of their taking armes, [it is ap]
parantly knowne, that
e generalitie of
e Provinces of
G[ueldres]
Utrecht
and
Overissel,
are addicted to poperie exceeding [ly and]
likewise this of
Holland
to all maner of religions: that [even here]
at the Hage, w
ch
is
e court of
e Contrey, and should [be best]
disposed, in all probabilitie to
e cause of religion, there [is not]
in
e judgement of those
at doe observe it, a quarter part of [the]
multitude well affected to religion: w
ch
I also meane, not [onely]
in hart and in deede but not so muche as in shewe, and [in outward]
profession. By reason wherof, and to eschewe
e perill [of the]
peoples soddaine inclination to accept of a Treaty, in ca[se that]
in
France
the
D. of Parma
should obtene any notable [victory]
I moved them rather to assigne a meetinge at
Berghen
o[r
Breda
]
and to licence the Ambassado
r
to come thither, or to some [other]
frontier towne, to negotiat w
t
suche persones as they mig[ht appoint]
and not to suffer him to enter into the hart of
e contrey: [or other]
wise to addresse their letters to
e Empero
r
himself, and [to his]
Ambassadors at
Brussels,
and w
t
out any walking in c[repusculo]
wherin they take a great delite in all their formes of pr[oceeding]
to shewe directly the causes,
at have moved them hithe[rto to]
disesteeme the Emperors offers, and to signifie plaine[ly what]
they thinke,
at if
e motion were made for a general [peace, and]
that
e Enemie would be brought to revoke his forces [out of]
France, they will then be very willing to come to some [conference]
But notw
t
standing this remonstrance, it was thought [ex]
pedient, to permitte him to come hither. I was w
t
him s[ince his]
comming, but then there passed nothinge but complement
[between us]
Howebeit he hath sent unto me sins, that wee might m[eet again]
tomorrowe meaninge as it seemeth, and as I see by some [circumstance]
fol.12r
[to] breake his minde about e Treaty, and to note what I will
answear. As his dealing shall require, I will be very diligent
to advertise yo
r
L.
And so I take my humble leave. Hage
Ja
n
27 1591.
